document.title: English Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools March 2024

9F821BC3B458470099A751CF2B722C50.description:
Demonstrate ethical and responsible use of all sources, including the Internet, Artificial
Intelligence (AI), and new technologies, as they develop.

19B8D59618DA4A51BE01BE0E25489A94.description:
Define plagiarism's meaning and legal consequences and follow ethical and legal
guidelines for gathering and using information.

F30093AD7A2D450D9ECA7DCB75BD191A.description:
Cite sources for quoted and paraphrased ideas using a standard method of documentation,
such as the Modern Language Association (MLA) or the American Psychological
Association (APA).

DB35B0980FF7487D8A3EC9ECE5727B90.description: Create research products aligned with the demands of the reading and writing standards.

BE4B1C83028944D5BEEA53774220F1E2.description: Synthesize multiple streams of information to support claims and introduce counterclaims.

17A9E2895B8647B8AE87ECEA64BE0E3B.description:
Analyze and evaluate the primary and secondary sources gathered for their credibility,
reliability, accuracy, and usefulness that includes identifying their main and supporting
ideas, points of view, conflicting information, and any misconceptions or biases.

A8833395EB2A4847A3EC2609E884F53F.description:
Gather and organize information from various sources, including internet resources,
electronic databases, and other technology.

A9078D189D034F21B2A7ED05B8B39FF2.description:
Formulate and revise questions about a research topic, broadening or narrowing the inquiry
as necessary.

C980F2D03C1E4615844C1225F29BD4B0.description:
The student will conduct research and read a series of conceptually related texts on
selected topics to build knowledge on grade-nine content, texts and areas prompted by
student interest.

85DD24237256491A8836042FC577CF9B.description:
Identify the possible cause and effect relationships between mass media coverage and
public opinion trends in media messages.

5F3297EBB3F94191BF0899E946BD7255.description:
Evaluate sources including advertisements, editorials, political cartoons, and feature stories
for relationships between intent and factual content.

A779634BD5CD4EBDAF6435BE4DDA406E.description:
Examine how values and viewpoints are included or excluded and how the media can
influence beliefs, behaviors, and interpretations.

988446D343D344CFB4C29BBEEA92A1DB.description: Evaluate the credibility, word choice, viewpoints, and bias in media presentations.

368F93414C2F40C7A26B753CE999B91C.description:
Analyze the persuasive techniques used in diverse media formats (e.g., name calling,
innuendo, glittering generalities, card stacking, bandwagon, testimonials, appeal to
prestige, snobbery or plain folks, appeal to emotion).

EE4713BDCA114A82AC280CC66839CA63.description: Determine the purpose of the media message and its effect on the audience.

7DD7ADA891224979B9F8BB7AF716DA0B.description: Create media messages for diverse audiences and purposes.

D05FA0A35BEE4DD2952EFB9D669E1BF1.description: Monitor, analyze, and use multiple streams of simultaneous information.

CAF676CEA8AA4388AABD81CD7FF2A2E0.description: Make strategic use of multimodal tools.

6BE76A80001E4D319C7C6D463BD2197C.description:
Memorize and accurately recite a short selection from a longer text demonstrating
inflection and meaningful expression that is appropriate to the tone and voice of the
selection.

E2375E29ED5B4E0AA85C30EE31B6D448.description:
Analyzing the effectiveness of one’s presentation, including introduction, central
idea, organization, and conclusion.

443DB0ED2FD8416691B3D3B465219200.description:
Using listening and speaking strategies effectively with awareness of verbal and
nonverbal cues (e.g., using body language to indicate attentiveness, and giving
appropriate feedback).

0DC2816E93E94883BA738C23FD8E65C8.description:
Choosing vocabulary, language and tone appropriate to the topic, audience, and
purpose.

72ED7282AAFE4B888AC258660E55F8E7.description: Report orally on a topic or text or present an opinion. This includes:

8EEAE515FDAA40BDB251A354215A085C.description:
Using reflection to evaluate one’s own role and the process in paired or small-group
activities.

D7DE5685324A42C9BDB45AEC6E6815EE.description: Summarizing points of agreement and disagreement.

BBBEAA58E7B44D98825BDF0E414C8212.description:
Responding thoughtfully and tactfully with evidence to diverse perspectives,
including challenging, clarifying, or verifying ideas and conclusions.

6E027EAC170E4722BBA085A85C086705.description: Setting clear goals and deadlines and defining individual roles as needed.

710B64D1C6C9405FB6B4EF2F359426B3.description:
Incorporating all group members in the development of new understandings,
making decisions, and solving problems.

D23FD30D7AD94CA7A675C0AD63DEF35B.description: Setting guidelines for group presentations and discussions.

6B60429BA6EB456A81088922BCC43EEA.description:
Applying a variety of strategies to listen actively and speak purposefully and
respectfully.

8638D3742B3D421FB1D75C9152A2359B.description:
Facilitate and contribute to a range of sustained collaborative discussions with diverse
partners on grade nine topics and texts. This includes:

0AD2D4BCDBD34C51B6605A327E691282.description:
The student will develop effective oral communication and collaboration skills to build a
community of learners that process, understand, and interpret content together.

EB4F137ABED3435684C981E772A9FF44.description: Spell correctly, consulting reference materials to check as needed.

A5C5087267D4424F804EC712097023B2.description:
Apply a style manual, such as that of the Modern Language Association (MLA) or the
American Psychological Association (APA) to apply rules for citing sources.

9439B95ACE054F5EAD72DBDE05F02139.description:
Use commas and semicolons to distinguish and divide main and subordinate clauses to link
two or more closely related independent clauses when writing.

8B38229B459542E8A5D1F143462205BB.description: Maintain consistent verb tense when speaking and writing.

BF7117ED97484B4D936457CA73AFF8D8.description:
Use appositives and main and subordinate clauses to convey and clarify a message when
speaking and writing.

B40AA5336340457087C5341BB9F5568F.description: Use and apply the active and passive voice as appropriate when speaking and writing.

560FAEB803ED48B3BB202FA7D19C32C8.description: Craft and apply a variety of sentence structures to infuse sentence variety in writing.

EDC31B1F01B54A32AE43E9C20FD625BB.description:
Use parallel structure across sentences and paragraphs to link and compare/contrast ideas in
writing and speaking.

A43BBAC402FF42C29C18B3AEB5504290.description:
The student will use the conventions of Standard English when speaking and writing,
differentiating between contexts that call for formal English and situations where informal
discourse is more appropriate.

7B2178ADD116420DB31FDCFD12E50897.description:
Edit writing for appropriate conventions, style, and language (See Language Usage for
grade level expectations).

DECA18B6BEFE4ADDB6971693779E6A84.description:
Use peer- and self-evaluation to edit writing for clarity and quality of information,
addressing strengths and making suggestions regarding how writing might be improved.

B3E46215E9974B2FA36EC6306992D079.description: Revise writing for clarity of content, accuracy, and adequate elaboration.

F517CACD3AA84B8FA9AAD7D0BF6DE1D1.description:
Identifying and addressing counterarguments and providing a rebuttal where
appropriate.

BCF2913C6B394B759E4A762CCBD19E6E.description:
Using background knowledge to expand ideas and add depth, utilizing reference
materials when necessary.

7CEE71AB97D44B31A47112C6D1FA6A39.description:
Using transitions, precise vocabulary, and sentence variety to create a cohesive
structure that shows the relationship between arguments, evidence, and ideas.

DAAB21FE56374AC09E1327D04985AFC7.description:
Establishing, supporting, and maintaining a central idea with evidence throughout a
piece of writing, organizing ideas in a logical sequence to exhibit unity.

C346D18B2EF848AC99982937EBDEE62B.description:
Composing a thesis statement that clearly communicates the writer’s position or
assertion.

896439526E714B6DA5484C302A6C742D.description:
Plan and organize writing to address a specific audience and purpose using the writing
process (planning, drafting, revising, editing). This includes:

D32D350408BE4D3395FC143687B745AF.description:
Develop flexibility in writing by routinely producing shorter and longer pieces for a range
of tasks, purposes, and audiences (e.g., summaries, reflections, descriptions, critiques,
letters, poetry, narratives, etc.).

ADFDB069CD1F497D832FF42476BB887B.description:
Write reflectively in response to readings in which students compare two or more texts
with details, examples, and other textual evidence to support an idea or position.

0AC335AE469949C6B901012C5373E77D.description:
Provide a concluding section that follows from the information or explanation
presented.

5F12CF75F8FB469BB993CE9541B14A5A.description:
Develop the topic through sustained use of the most significant and relevant facts,
concrete details, quotations, or other information from multiple authoritative sources
appropriate to the audience's knowledge.

C572EB1D9E8E4EE2BCCCBD18D6D06982.description: Adopt an organizational structure that clarifies relationships among ideas and concepts.

C476750094244AB88FE632A7732313BC.description:
Introduce a topic clearly by providing context, presenting well-defined theses, and
previewing what follows.

2CCB2DB35E604F4AAAB1D74A063F4D37.description:
The student will write in various forms for diverse audiences and purposes linked to
grade nine content and texts with an emphasis on expository and persuasive writing.

E0A27E4D60824ED89A03737E57BB8395.description:
Evaluate the clarity and accuracy of information found in informational texts, corroborating
or challenging conclusions with other sources of information.

642558D0B04945CA8EED5597723956C8.description:
Compare the perspectives and viewpoints of two or more authors regarding their treatment
of the same or similar topics, including the details they include and emphasize in their
respective accounts as well as the impact of each author’s qualifications.

4B1A2B230FCC49D2B963210960D29C57.description:
Analyze how authors use rhetorical devices to create ethos, logos, and pathos and impact
the reader.

98F4E99520F5425B89334CDD3B04810E.description:
Analyze an author’s word choice and use of rhetorical devices to persuade or convince an
audience.

FB73595C32744FCA8FF6F8C479A88F70.description:
Compare characteristics of expository, technical, and persuasive texts, including their
differences in purpose, format, and text structure.

1F21076DEF83484A8FB5BB05B847DDAE.description:
Distinguish among, facts, reasoned judgments, and/or speculation in texts to determine
where a position/argument is to be confirmed, disproved, or modified.

A38CFA41FBA04E8EA366D29A984D65B9.description:
Explain the purpose and interpret the use of data and information in maps, charts, graphs,
timelines, tables, and diagrams in informational, historical, scientific, or technical texts.

053E0DD13D7347E8BA98C5C914C60BDC.description:
Analyze the development of main ideas over the course of texts, including how they
emerge, are shaped, and are refined by specific details to help reveal the author’s intended
purpose for writing.

5158962DCBFA4D259F776A3C5D523EB3.description:
The student will use textual evidence to demonstrate comprehension and build
knowledge from grade-level complex informational texts read.

3C808F9C419847B4BE41F2454EE63D00.description:
Explain the relationships between and among particular literary elements of a story or play,
including how the setting shapes the plot and characters.

5E86C6C4FBE14D76B211780CC68089C7.description:
Describe how the historical or social function of a text depends on its context (e.g., cultural,
situational, historical, geographical).

EF232568DB1D48CCA0A74CDC35CC0B0C.description:
Explain the point of view and distinguish between what is implied or intended because of
the use of hyperbole, irony, sarcasm, and understatement.

B5B2B3A8548244D3ACAB0D296A584894.description:
Explain how an author’s specific word choices, syntax, tone, and voice shape the meaning
of the text.

8511796FE9614BBDBB32B4882587D445.description:
Analyze the use of rhyme, rhythm, sound, imagery, and other literary devices in poetry to
convey a message and elicit a reader’s emotions.

37635AE434934CC3943EBAF734D641CD.description:
Identify and describe how dramatic conventions (e.g., soliloquy, aside, narration, direct
address to the audience) contribute to the theme and effect of plays from various cultures.

7F00A50393AE47CEAC1B050B35934F13.description:
Differentiate between character types in literary texts (e.g., dynamic/round character,
static/flat character, and stereotype) and their impact on the theme.

759A3FBC20FC43EE94B23CB5602CF451.description:
Examine and analyze the characteristics that distinguish literary forms (e.g., fiction,
nonfiction, poetry, prose, novel, drama, essay, speech) and analyze how the differing
structure of each literary form contributes to its meaning and style.

356B5A5846EC4B78B3C3EB30B707D981.description:
Explain stated or implied themes, analyzing their development over the course of texts, and
the relationship of characters, setting, and plot to those themes.

F8246776A222481CB21CA4336CAB7F61.description:
The student will use textual evidence to demonstrate comprehension and build
knowledge from a variety of grade-level complex literary texts read to include narratives,
literary nonfiction, poetry, and drama.

E39C29A4CF7C4778808E7E65572B4EFD.description:
Use newly learned words and phrases in multiple contexts, including students’ discussions
and speaking and writing activities.

D118368FCCBD4AFBB00D65F2A4FE3716.description:
Explain the meaning of literary and classical allusions and figurative language in context
and analyze their roles in texts.

2BBF6C0DCB504FBA9E9B2A7011AF0B0D.description: Identify and explain idiomatic language in context.

1B8A4C3F88E34D9BA39B77424EDD23DE.description:
Discriminate between the connotative and denotative meanings and interpret the
connotation(s).

CD67196A8484452CA51D19AD7F9EB8DA.description:
Use structural analysis of roots, affixes, and etymology to explain the meanings of
unfamiliar and complex words.

FAAFDE450A1C4EB1A9A512FF8DFF840F.description:
Use context and sentence structure to clarify the literal and figurative meanings of words
and phrases.

54DAFDCE5A8441FE94C9A403FF23315A.description:
Develop and accurately use general academic and content-specific vocabulary through
reading, discussing, and writing about grade-level texts and topics.

B0428126D22147A9AAA68AC85433D5C5.description:
The student will systematically build vocabulary and word knowledge based on grade
nine content and texts.

FE0651383E3E48F88AB5865129C31B48.description:
Use reading strategies as needed to aid and monitor comprehension when encountering
challenging sections of text. These sense-making strategies attend to text structure,
common organizational structures, summarizing, asking questions of the text, and others
(Reading Strategies, 3-12).

6E45221D0F7A4D6F9409B2D28CF33D54.description:
Regularly engage in reading a series of conceptually related texts organized around topics
of study to build knowledge and vocabulary (These texts should be at a range of
complexity levels so students can read the texts independently, with peers, or with modest
support.). Use this background knowledge as context for new learning (Deep Reading on
Topics to Build Knowledge and Vocabulary, K-12).

198B70A22C264DCF80D4F474408ED08F.description:
When responding to text through discussions and/or writing, draw several pieces of
evidence from grade-level complex texts to support claims, conclusions, and inferences,
including quoting or paraphrasing from texts accurately and tracing where relevant
evidence is located (Textual Evidence, K-12).

09B0B56E74F34DB582D8456CDDC0E8B3.description:
Proficiently read and comprehend a variety of literary and informational texts that exhibit
complexity at the lower range of the grades 9-10 band. (See the Quantitative and
Qualitative Analysis charts for determining complexity in the Appendix.) (Text
Complexity, 2-12).

ED0758CC6629436CA8BD74144B12D7CF.description:
Read a variety of grade-level complex text with accuracy, automaticity, appropriate rate,
and meaningful expression in successive readings to support comprehension. Monitor
while reading to confirm or self-correct word recognition and understanding, as necessary
(Reading Fluency, K-12).

2882DDF84EDD475A8061C4BBE795CA2A.description:
The student will build knowledge and comprehension skills from reading a range of
challenging, content-rich texts. This includes fluently reading and gathering evidence from
grade-level complex texts, reading widely on topics to gain purposeful knowledge and
vocabulary, and using reading strategies when comprehension breaks down.

9D370C6B49F041D78750DA85B6E08EA3.description: Developing Skilled Readers and Building Reading Stamina
